back: A group of connected devices that share information and resources.
A device on a network that sends or receives data — like a PC, phone, or server.
A host that provides services or data to other devices on the network.
A host that requests and uses services from a server.
A simple network where devices share files or printers without a central server.

front: What are the three main components of a network?
back: Devices, media, and services.
The cables or signals that carry data between devices — like copper, fiber, or wireless.
A device like a switch or router that manages data flow between hosts.
A diagram showing where devices and cables are placed in a network.
A diagram showing how data flows through the network, regardless of cable layout.
Local Area Network — a network covering a small area like a home, office, or building.
Wide Area Network — a network that spans large distances, like between cities or countries.
Internet Service Provider — a company that gives you access to the internet.

front: What does IP address stand for?
back: Internet Protocol address — a unique number that identifies a device on a network.
Network Interface Card — hardware inside a device that connects it to a network.
Domain Name System — it translates website names into IP addresses.
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol — it automatically gives IP addresses to devices.

front: What does MAC address stand for?
back: Media Access Control address — a unique ID given to every network device.
Hypertext Transfer Protocol — the basic rule for loading websites in a browser.
Uniform Resource Locator — it’s the full address of a website, like https://example.com.
A network device that connects devices in a LAN and forwards data only to the correct destination.
A device that connects different networks and chooses the best path for data to travel.
A small piece of data sent across a network, containing both the data and destination info.
Transmission Control Protocol — ensures reliable, ordered delivery of data.
User Datagram Protocol — sends data quickly without checking for errors or delivery.
A set of rules that devices follow to communicate on a network.
The maximum amount of data that can move through a network link per second.
The delay it takes for data to travel from source to destination.
File Transfer Protocol — used to upload or download files over a network.
A security device or software that controls what data is allowed in or out of a network.

front: What does IOS stand for in Cisco devices?
back: Internetwork Operating System — the software that controls routers and switches.
Command Line Interface — a text-based way to interact with Cisco devices.
A physical port used to configure a device directly, even with no network.
Secure Shell — a secure way to remotely access a device using CLI.
An insecure method to remotely access a device — sends data as plain text.

front: What is the purpose of a hostname?
back: To give a switch or router a unique name for identification.
Virtual Terminal Lines — used for remote CLI access like SSH or Telnet.

front: What is a banner message in Cisco IOS?
back: A legal warning shown to users when they access the device.

front: What is the difference between running-config and startup-config?
back: Running-config is active in RAM; startup-config is stored in NVRAM for reboot.

front: What is a Switch Virtual Interface (SVI)?
back: A software-based interface used to manage a switch remotely using an IP address.
A password used to enter privileged EXEC mode — stored in plain text.

front: What is the enable secret password?
back: A secure password that also gives access to privileged EXEC mode — it is encrypted.

front: What is the console password used for?
back: To control access to the device through the local console port.

front: What is the VTY password used for?
back: To control remote access through Telnet or SSH.

front: What does the 'login' command do on a line?
back: It tells the device to prompt for a password on that line.
The basic mode with limited commands — shown by the '>' prompt.
Gives access to all commands — shown by the '#' prompt.
A mode where you can make system-wide changes like setting hostname or passwords.
A sub-mode used to configure settings on a specific interface like FastEthernet0/1.
It moves you back one level in the CLI.

front: What is RAM used for in Cisco devices?
back: It stores the running configuration and active processes — lost when the device is turned off.
It stores the startup configuration — kept when power is off.
It stores the IOS image and other system files — kept when power is off.

front: What is the purpose of ROM in a Cisco device?
back: It holds startup instructions, like a basic bootloader — not used for configuration.
Displays the current active configuration in RAM.
Shows the saved configuration in NVRAM that loads on reboot.

front: What does 'show ip interface brief' do?
back: Gives a quick summary of all interfaces and their IP status.
Saves the current configuration so it is used after a reboot.

front: What is the purpose of the 'reload' command?
back: It restarts the device — used to test or apply changes after saving.

front: What is stored in the startup-config?
back: The saved settings that load when the device reboots.
A set of rules that devices use to communicate on a network.

front: What are the three parts of communication?
back: Source, Destination, and Channel.
Breaking a large message into smaller pieces before sending it over the network.
Adding headers and trailers to data so it can move through the network.
Removing headers and trailers from data at the receiving device.
A method to make sure the sender doesn’t send data too fast for the receiver.
A group of related protocols that work together to complete a network task.
Transmission Control Protocol / Internet Protocol — the main protocol suite for the internet.
A 7-layer reference model used to explain how network communication works.

front: What is the purpose of the TCP/IP model?
back: It defines how data moves across a network using four layers.

front: What are the 7 layers of the OSI model?
back: Application, Presentation, Session, Transport, Network, Data Link, Physical.

front: What is a simple way to remember the OSI layers?
back: "All People Seem To Need Data Processing" — from top (Layer 7) to bottom (Layer 1).

front: What are the 4 layers of the TCP/IP model?
back: Application, Transport, Internet, Network Access.

front: What layer of the OSI model does IP work at?
back: Layer 3 — the Network Layer.

front: What layer of the OSI model does MAC addressing happen at?
back: Layer 2 — the Data Link Layer.
Data sent from one device directly to one other device.
Data sent to a group of specific devices at the same time.
Data sent to all devices on a network segment.
A data unit at Layer 2 that includes MAC addresses and error checking.
A data unit at Layer 3 that includes IP addresses.

front: What is the purpose of the Physical Layer?
back: To transport raw bits over the network media using signals.
Network Interface Card — connects a device to the network physically.
A method to convert bits into recognizable signal patterns for transmission.
The way 1s and 0s are represented on the medium — like electrical pulses or light.
The capacity of a medium to carry data, measured in bits per second.
The total time it takes for data to travel from source to destination.
The actual amount of data successfully transferred over time.
The usable data transferred over time — throughput minus overhead like headers.
Electromagnetic Interference — interference from external electrical signals.
Radio Frequency Interference — signal disruption from other radio sources.

front: What is the binary number system?
back: A base-2 system using only 1s and 0s — used by computers to represent data.
A single binary digit — either 1 or 0.
A group of 8 bits — forms part of an IPv4 address.
A group of 8 bits — same as an octet.

front: What is the decimal number system?
back: A base-10 system using digits 0 through 9 — used by humans.

front: What is the hexadecimal number system?
back: A base-16 system using digits 0–9 and letters A–F — used in IPv6 and MAC addresses.

front: How many bits are in an IPv4 address?
back: 32 bits — divided into four 8-bit octets.

front: How many bits are in an IPv6 address?
back: 128 bits — shown as 32 hexadecimal characters.
A group of four hexadecimal digits in an IPv6 address.

front: Why is hexadecimal used in networking?
back: It’s shorter and easier to read than binary — used in IPv6 and MAC addressing.

front: How do you convert binary to decimal?
back: Add the values of the bits that are set to 1 using powers of 2.

front: What is the value of each position in an 8-bit binary number?
back: 128, 64, 32, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1 — from left to right.

front: How do you convert decimal to binary?
back: Subtract powers of 2 from the decimal number and mark each bit as 1 or 0.

front: How many values can 8 bits represent?
back: 256 values — from 0 to 255.

front: How do you convert hex to binary?
back: Convert each hex digit into a 4-bit binary number.

front: How do you convert binary to hex?
back: Group the bits in sets of 4 and convert each group to a hex digit.

front: What is the decimal value of binary 11110000?
What is the binary of decimal 192?
What is the hex value of binary 10101100?
back: AC

front: What is the binary of hex 3F?
What is the main job of the Data Link Layer?
back: To package Layer 3 packets into frames and move them across the physical network.

front: What are the two sublayers of the Data Link Layer?
back: Logical Link Control (LLC) and Media Access Control (MAC).

front: What does the LLC sublayer do?
back: Provides interface to Layer 3 and controls frame creation and delivery.

front: What does the MAC sublayer do?
back: Controls how frames are placed on and taken off the media — handles physical addressing.
A Layer 2 data unit with headers, data, and trailer used for transmission.
A unique hardware address assigned to a network interface — used for local delivery.

front: What is FCS in a frame?
back: Frame Check Sequence — used to detect errors with a CRC check.

front: What is the difference between physical and logical topology?
back: Physical shows cable layout; logical shows how data flows between nodes.
Devices take turns to send data — only one can talk at a time.
Devices can send and receive data at the same time — no waiting.
A single central cable connects all devices — used in early Ethernet networks.
All devices connect to a central device like a switch — most common today.
Each device connects to two others in a loop — data travels in one direction.
Devices are interconnected — each device can reach others directly.
A direct connection between two devices — common in WAN links.
A mix of two or more basic topologies — like star-ring or star-bus.
Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection — used in Ethernet to detect and recover from collisions.
Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Avoidance — used in Wi-Fi to avoid collisions before sending.

front: Why is CSMA/CD not used in modern Ethernet?
back: Because switches and full-duplex links eliminate collisions.
In wireless networks — devices check before transmitting to avoid collisions.
Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection — used to detect and handle collisions in Ethernet.

front: What is the minimum size of an Ethernet frame?
back: 64 bytes — smaller frames are dropped as collision fragments.

front: What is the maximum size of a standard Ethernet frame?
back: 1518 bytes — larger frames are called jumbo or giant frames.
A unique 48-bit hardware address assigned to a network interface card (NIC).

front: How many hexadecimal digits are in a MAC address?
back: 12 hexadecimal digits — equal to 6 bytes or 48 bits.

front: What is the OUI in a MAC address?
back: Organizationally Unique Identifier — the first 3 bytes that identify the device vendor.

front: What is a unicast MAC address?
back: A unique MAC address for a single device — used in direct communication.

front: What is the broadcast MAC address?
back: FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF — used to send frames to all devices on the local network.

front: What is a MAC address table?
back: A table in a switch that maps MAC addresses to specific ports — used for forwarding frames.
A method where the switch reads the whole frame and checks for errors before forwarding it.
A method where the switch starts forwarding a frame as soon as it reads the destination MAC address.
A switching method that reads the first 64 bytes of a frame before forwarding to avoid collision fragments.

front: What does a switch do when it receives a frame with an unknown MAC address?
back: It floods the frame out of all ports except the one it was received on.

front: What does a switch do when it receives a frame for a known MAC address?
back: It forwards the frame only to the port associated with that MAC in its table.
It defines if a device can send and receive data at the same time (full) or not (half).
A feature that automatically adjusts the port to use straight-through or crossover cable type.

front: What happens if two connected ports have different duplex settings?
back: It creates a duplex mismatch — leading to collisions, errors, and poor performance.

front: What does the switch do with a frame that fails the FCS check?
back: It drops the frame — the frame is considered corrupted.
When a switch sends a frame out all ports because it doesn't know the destination MAC.

front: What is a switch's MAC address table sometimes called?
back: A Content Addressable Memory (CAM) table.

front: What is the main function of the network layer?
back: To move packets between different networks using logical addressing (IP).
Internet Protocol — the main protocol used to send packets across networks.

front: What is encapsulation at the network layer?
back: Adding an IP header to a transport layer segment to form a packet.

front: What are the two main IP versions?
back: IPv4 and IPv6.
A protocol that sends data without setting up a dedicated connection first — like IP.
IP will try to deliver packets but does not guarantee delivery or order.

front: What does media independent mean for IP?
back: IP can work over any type of physical media (copper, fiber, wireless).
Splitting a large IPv4 packet into smaller pieces to fit the MTU of a network link.
To reduce processing and improve performance — fragmentation is handled before sending.
A Layer 3 data unit that contains an IP header and the payload from the transport layer.
A database used by routers to determine where to send packets next.
A router that handles traffic when the destination is outside the local network.

front: What are the three types of routes in a routing table?
back: Directly connected, static, and dynamic.

front: What is a directly connected route?
back: A route to a network that is physically connected to one of the router’s interfaces.
A manually configured route that doesn’t change unless updated by an admin.
A route learned automatically through a routing protocol like OSPF or EIGRP.

front: What is the purpose of the IP header?
back: It contains source and destination IP addresses and control information.
Maximum Transmission Unit — the largest size a packet can be on a link.
Splits IPv4 packets into smaller pieces to fit within the MTU of a network link.
IPv6 hosts handle fragmentation before sending to reduce router load.
A physical address used by NICs to identify devices on the same local network.
A logical address used to identify devices across different networks.
Address Resolution Protocol — used by IPv4 to find a MAC address for a known IP.
A list of IP addresses and their matching MAC addresses stored in memory.

front: What happens when an ARP table has no entry for a device?
back: The device sends an ARP broadcast asking who has that IP address.
Displays the ARP table on a Windows PC.

front: What does 'show ip arp' do on a router?
back: Displays the ARP table on a Cisco router.
A type of attack where a device sends fake ARP replies to mislead the network.
An IPv6 process that replaces ARP to resolve MAC addresses and discover routers.

front: What is a Neighbor Solicitation message?
back: An ICMPv6 message sent to learn the MAC address of a known IPv6 address.

front: What is a Neighbor Advertisement in IPv6?
back: A response to a Neighbor Solicitation that gives the MAC address of the IPv6 device.

front: What is the difference between ARP and ND?
back: ARP is for IPv4, uses broadcasts; ND is for IPv6, uses ICMPv6 messages and multicast.

front: What is the lifetime of an ARP table entry?
back: Entries stay in the ARP table for a limited time before they are removed — usually a few minutes.

front: What happens after a device replies to an ARP request?
back: The requester adds the IP-MAC mapping to its ARP table.
A device sends an ARP request for its own IP — used to detect conflicts or update tables.

front: Why is ARP a security risk?
back: It trusts replies without checking — attackers can send fake replies (ARP spoofing).
A malicious technique where fake ARP messages are used to link an IP to the wrong MAC.

front: How can you reduce ARP attacks?
back: Use features like Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI) and static ARP entries.

front: What type of message does ND use instead of broadcast?
back: Multicast — to reduce traffic and limit scope.

front: What layer does ARP operate at?
back: It works between Layer 2 (MAC) and Layer 3 (IP) — sometimes called Layer 2.5.

front: What does the command 'hostname' do on a router?
back: Sets the device name shown in the CLI prompt.
A secure, encrypted password for privileged EXEC mode.
Access settings for the router's console port.
Access settings for Telnet/SSH remote sessions.

front: What does the 'login' command do in line config?
back: Enables password checking for that line.
Encrypts all passwords in the configuration file.

front: What is the purpose of a 'banner motd'?
back: Displays a legal warning message to users before login.
Saves the active configuration to NVRAM so it's kept after a reboot.

front: What does the 'no shutdown' command do on an interface?
back: Enables the interface and brings it up.

front: What is the default gateway for a host?
back: The IP address of the router interface used to send data to other networks.
A 32-bit address made of four octets used to identify devices on a network.

front: What is an octet in an IP address?
back: A group of 8 bits — each IPv4 address has 4 octets.

front: What does a subnet mask do?
back: It shows which part of the IP address is the network and which part is the host.

front: What is the purpose of a prefix length?
back: It tells how many bits are used for the network part (e.g., /24).
The lowest address in a subnet — identifies the entire network, not a device.
The highest address in a subnet — used to send data to all devices in that network.
Any address between the network and broadcast address — can be assigned to a device.
An address used to send data to one specific device.

front: What is a broadcast address in IPv4?
back: An address used to send data to all devices in a local network.
An address used to send data to a group of selected devices.
Addresses that are not routable on the internet — used in internal networks.

front: What are the three private IP ranges?
What is a public IP address?
back: An IP address that can be used on the internet — must be unique globally.
127.0.0.1 — used to test the local network stack.

front: What is the 169.254.0.0/16 range used for?
back: Link-local addressing — used when a device can't get an IP from DHCP.
Breaking a larger network into smaller ones to organize and manage IPs better.

front: What is the purpose of subnetting?
back: To reduce broadcast domains and make more efficient use of IP addresses.
A 32-bit number that separates the network part from the host part of an IP address.
Classless Inter-Domain Routing — uses prefix lengths like /24 instead of class-based rules.

front: What is the magic number method?
back: A shortcut to find subnet ranges by subtracting the subnet block from 256.

front: What is a 'magic number' in subnetting?
back: The block size — found by subtracting the subnet mask value from 256.

front: How do you find the subnet increment using the magic number?
back: Subtract the subnet mask octet from 256 (e.g., 256 - 192 = 64).

front: If the subnet mask is 255.255.255.224, what is the magic number?
If the subnet mask is 255.255.255.240, what is the block size?
back: 256 - 240 = 16 — subnets start at 0, 16, 32, etc.

front: What is the first valid host in the 192.168.1.64/26 subnet?
back: 192.168.1.65 — one above the network address.

front: What is the last valid host in the 192.168.1.64/26 subnet?
back: 192.168.1.126 — one below the broadcast address.

front: What is the broadcast address for 192.168.1.64/26?
back: 192.168.1.127 — the last address in the block.

front: How many hosts can a /26 subnet support?
back: 64 addresses total, minus 2 — so 62 usable hosts.
It has 4 addresses — 2 usable hosts, 1 network address, 1 broadcast.

front: Why is the magic number helpful?
back: It quickly shows subnet boundaries and helps find valid IP ranges.

front: What is the magic number for a /25 subnet?
back: 256 - 128 = 128 — subnet blocks are 0–127 and 128–255.

front: What are the valid host ranges for a /25 network starting at 192.168.10.0?
What is the broadcast address for the 192.168.10.128/25 subnet?
What is the magic number for a /27 subnet?
What is the network address for 192.168.5.77/27?
back: 192.168.5.64 — it falls in the 64–95 block.

front: What is the broadcast address for 192.168.5.64/27?
What is the valid host range for 192.168.5.64/27?
What is the magic number for a /28 subnet?
How many usable hosts in a /28?
back: 16 total IPs — 14 usable hosts.
10.0.5.16 — because 23 falls in the 16–31 block.

front: What is the size of an IPv6 address?
back: 128 bits — written in hexadecimal and divided into eight 16-bit blocks (hextets).
A group of 16 bits (4 hex characters) in an IPv6 address.
Stateless Address Autoconfiguration — a method for devices to self-configure IPv6 addresses using RA messages.
An IPv6 address used for communication within the same local link — starts with fe80::/10.

front: What is a Global Unicast Address (GUA)?
back: A routable IPv6 address assigned by an ISP — similar to a public IPv4 address.
An ICMPv6 message sent by a host to discover IPv6 routers on the network.
An ICMPv6 message sent by a router with IPv6 info like prefix, gateway, and DNS.
An ICMPv6 message used to discover the MAC address of another IPv6 device or check if it is reachable.
An ICMPv6 message sent in response to a Neighbor Solicitation — includes MAC info.

front: What does the ping command do?
back: Sends ICMP Echo Requests to test if a device is reachable and measures round-trip time.

front: What is the IPv6 loopback address?
back: ::1 — used to test internal networking on a device.

front: What is the IPv6 unspecified address?
back: :: — used when a device doesn't yet have an IP address.
A method to auto-generate an interface ID for IPv6 using the device’s MAC address.

front: What does DAD stand for in IPv6?
back: Duplicate Address Detection — checks if an address is already in use on the network.

front: What are the first 3 bits of a Global Unicast Address (GUA)?
back: They are always 001 — GUAs usually start with 2xxx or 3xxx.

front: What is a multicast address in IPv6?
back: An address that sends traffic to a group of devices — starts with ff00::/8.

front: What is the all-nodes multicast address?
back: ff02::1 — used to reach all IPv6 devices on a local link.

front: What is the all-routers multicast address?
back: ff02::2 — used to reach all IPv6 routers on the local link.

front: How is IPv6 address compression done?
back: By removing leading zeros and replacing one group of consecutive zeros with '::'.

front: Can you use '::' more than once in an IPv6 address?
back: No — '::' can only be used once to avoid confusion when decompressing.

front: What type of IPv6 address is fe80::/10?
back: Link-Local Address — used for communication on the same network segment.

front: What type of IPv6 address starts with ff00::/8?
back: Multicast Address — used to send packets to multiple devices.
The unspecified address — used when a device doesn’t yet have an address.
The loopback address — used to test the local TCP/IP stack.

front: What is the IPv6 all-nodes multicast address?
back: ff02::1 — targets all devices on the local network.

front: What is the IPv6 all-routers multicast address?
back: ff02::2 — used to reach all routers on the link.

front: What is the IPv6 solicited-node multicast address?
back: An address used for Neighbor Discovery — helps a host find another host’s MAC address.

front: What is the prefix for IPv6 documentation examples?
back: 2001:db8::/32 — used in books and training.
To send error messages, ping replies, and support Neighbor Discovery in IPv6.

front: What is the IPv6 equivalent of ARP?
back: Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP) — uses ICMPv6 instead of broadcasts.
Sends ICMP Echo Request messages to test if a device is reachable.

front: What response indicates a successful ping?
back: An ICMP Echo Reply is received from the target device.
ICMP — Internet Control Message Protocol.

front: What is the difference between 'ping' and 'tracert'?
back: 'ping' tests reachability; 'tracert' shows the path a packet takes to the destination.
Trace Route — it lists each hop a packet takes to reach its target.

front: What does a '*' in traceroute output mean?
back: No response was received from that hop — it could be filtered or down.

front: What does the TTL field do in traceroute?
back: It limits how many hops a packet can make — used to trace each step.

front: What is the equivalent of 'ping' for IPv6?
back: ping6 or ping -6 — used to test IPv6 connectivity.

front: What is the equivalent of 'tracert' for IPv6?
back: tracert -6 or traceroute6 — shows the path for IPv6 packets.

front: What does a ping test help diagnose?
back: Connectivity issues, network delays, or unreachable devices.
Transmission Control Protocol — a connection-oriented protocol that ensures reliable, ordered delivery of data.
User Datagram Protocol — a fast, connectionless protocol with low overhead and no guaranteed delivery.
A numerical identifier used to direct data to specific services or applications on a host.
A combination of IP address and port number used to identify a specific connection.
Malicious software designed to harm, steal, or disrupt data or systems.
Distributed Denial of Service — uses multiple systems to flood and disrupt a network or service.

front: What is AAA in network security?
back: Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting — controls who can access, what they can do, and keeps a record.

front: What is a DMZ in networking?
back: Demilitarized Zone — a network segment exposed to external traffic, used to host public services securely.
A record of normal network performance used for comparison during troubleshooting.
Quality of Service — prioritizing some types of traffic (like voice or video) to reduce delay and improve performance.

front: What is window size in TCP?
back: The amount of data that can be sent before receiving an acknowledgment.
The TCP process to establish a connection: SYN, SYN-ACK, ACK.

front: What is a SYN flood attack?
back: A type of DoS attack that overwhelms a system by sending many TCP connection requests without completing them.

front: What is the function of a firewall?
back: To filter traffic based on rules and protect a network from unauthorized access.
Tricking people into giving up sensitive information or access — not a technical attack.
Network Address Translation — allows private IP addresses to be used with a single public IP.
Port Address Translation — a type of NAT where multiple devices share one public IP using different ports.
Having backup systems or paths to ensure reliability if one part fails.
The ability of a network to grow and handle increased traffic or users.
The layout of devices and connections in a network — physical or logical.
A person or group that tries to gain unauthorized access to a network, often using software exploits or stolen credentials.
Malicious software that damages or steals data, disrupts systems, or gives unauthorized access.
A group of infected devices controlled by an attacker, used in DDoS attacks.
Virtual Private Network — a secure connection over the internet that protects data from interception.

front: What is the function of the show ip interface brief command?
back: It quickly displays the status and IP address of all interfaces on a router or switch.

front: What is the purpose of the ping command?
back: To test connectivity between two devices using ICMP echo request and reply messages.
It shows the path that packets take from source to destination, listing each router along the way.
A layered security strategy using multiple tools and techniques to protect a network.
A saved copy of device settings or data, used for recovery in case of failure or attack.

front: What is the purpose of IP addressing in a small network?
back: To give each device a unique address so data can be routed correctly and easily managed.
Hypertext Transfer Protocol — used for web browsing over the internet.
Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure — a secure version of HTTP that uses encryption.
File Transfer Protocol — used to upload and download files between systems.
Trivial File Transfer Protocol — a simpler version of FTP, often used for network booting or device configs.
Secure Shell — used for secure remote access to network devices using CLI.
Telecommunication Network — used for remote CLI access without encryption.
Domain Name System — translates website names to IP addresses.
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol — automatically assigns IP addresses to devices.
Simple Mail Transfer Protocol — used to send emails.
Post Office Protocol version 3 — used to retrieve emails from a server.
Internet Message Access Protocol — used to access and manage emails on a server.
Simple Network Management Protocol — used to monitor and manage network devices.
Internet Control Message Protocol — used for error reporting and testing connectivity (e.g., ping).
Address Resolution Protocol — maps an IP address to a MAC address on a local network.
Network Time Protocol — used to synchronize the time on networked devices.
Remote Desktop Protocol — used to remotely access and control another computer’s desktop.
Lightweight Directory Access Protocol — used for accessing and managing directory services.
Network Address Translation — allows multiple private IP addresses to share a single public IP.
Port Address Translation — a type of NAT that uses different port numbers for each connection.
Open Shortest Path First — a link-state routing protocol used within large networks.
Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol — a Cisco-proprietary distance-vector routing protocol.
Border Gateway Protocol — used to route data between different autonomous systems on the internet.
Routing Information Protocol — a distance-vector routing protocol with a hop-count limit.

front: What does AAA stand for in networking?
back: Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting — a security model for managing user access.
Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service — a centralized AAA protocol.
Terminal Access Controller Access-Control System Plus — a Cisco AAA protocol with more control than RADIUS.
Internet Service Provider — a company that provides access to the internet.
Local Area Network — a network that connects devices in a limited area like a home or office.
Wide Area Network — a network that covers a large area and connects multiple LANs.
Command Line Interface — a text-based way to interact with devices like routers and switches.
Virtual Local Area Network — it allows logical separation of devices on the same physical switch.
Switched Virtual Interface — a virtual interface used to manage and assign an IP address to a VLAN.
Media Access Control — a unique hardware address used for local delivery of frames.
Internet Protocol — provides logical addressing and routing for network communication.
Domain Name System — translates domain names into IP addresses.
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol — assigns IP addresses and other network settings to devices automatically.
Maximum Transmission Unit — the largest size a packet can be to travel across a link without fragmentation.

front: What does CAM stand for in switching?
back: Content Addressable Memory — used by switches to store MAC address tables.
Cyclic Redundancy Check — a method used to detect errors in frames.
Time To Live — a value that limits how many hops a packet can take before being dropped.

front: What port number does HTTP use?
back: Port 80 — used for unencrypted web traffic.

front: What port number does HTTPS use?
back: Port 443 — used for encrypted web traffic over SSL/TLS.

front: What port numbers does FTP use?
back: Ports 20 and 21 — 21 for control commands, 20 for data transfer.

front: What port number does SSH use?
back: Port 22 — used for secure remote login and CLI access.

front: What port number does Telnet use?
back: Port 23 — used for unencrypted remote CLI access.

front: What port number does DNS use?
back: Port 53 — used for both TCP and UDP queries to resolve names to IPs.

front: What port number does DHCP use?
back: Ports 67 and 68 — 67 for server to client, 68 for client to server (both use UDP).

front: What port number does SMTP use?
back: Port 25 — used to send emails between servers (usually TCP).

front: What port number does POP3 use?
back: Port 110 — used to download emails from a server.

front: What port number does IMAP use?
back: Port 143 — used to access and manage emails on a mail server.

front: What port number does TFTP use?
back: Port 69 — used for simple file transfers with no authentication or encryption (UDP).

front: What port number does SNMP use?
back: Port 161 — used by network management systems to monitor devices (UDP).

front: What port number does SNMP Trap use?
back: Port 162 — used to receive alerts from SNMP-enabled devices (UDP).

front: What port number does RDP use?
back: Port 3389 — used for Remote Desktop Protocol (Microsoft remote access).

front: What port number does NTP use?
back: Port 123 — used to synchronize time between network devices (UDP).

front: What port number does LDAP use?
back: Port 389 — used for accessing directory services like Microsoft Active Directory.

front: What port number does LDAPS use?
back: Port 636 — LDAP over SSL for secure directory access.

front: What port number does NetBIOS use?
back: Ports 137, 138, 139 — used for file and printer sharing in legacy Windows networks.

front: What port number does SMB use?
back: Port 445 — Server Message Block used for Windows file and printer sharing.

front: What port number does HTTPS use?
back: Port 443 — secure version of HTTP using SSL/TLS encryption.
